People have just stayed here for longer time , they dont know even single concept of programming , design , architecture.
All the work done by contractors from Accentures , Deloitte.
No Learning when it comes to learn technical concepts.
Frequent fights between the management and employees .
Good people leaving the company only chamchas can stay here

pros: Typical multinational programs found in this scale company
cons: Terribly toxic management practices allowed

review_title: Great place to work, getting better with some changes.
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Benefits package, work/life balance, bleeding-edge technology, snacks/drinks, onsite gym (HQ only), dental.

The benefits package is excellent and comprehensive. Management from top-down stresses a work-life balance, and strives to maintain it. As a leading software company, we have access to the absolute latest hardware and software provided by our partners. Free snacks/drinks in the cafeterias. At HQ, there is an onsite gym, and there's dental.
cons: The current restructuring is leaving many confused and concerned about the future. This needs to be accelerated beyond normal bounds to ensure the company is successful. Communicating between departments has always seemed to be a weak point. This needs to get resolved. In addition, support from departments within the company need to be second-nature. We shouldn't have to beg for support from another department to get it.

review_title: Competitive atmosphere, you'll go as far as your skills and ambition will allow. No free rides or automatic promotions.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Stock options are not overly generous, but the company is public and they do tend to pay off, mostly. Products sell themselves. Collegial atmosphere. Freedom to experiment, make mistakes. I've seen talented people  go from individual contributor to Senior director and even VP. You may hire in at a particular level, but promotions are not automatic or guaranteed. This leads to quality in management.
cons:
Career paths not clearly defined. Due to lack of automatic promotion, career paths have been put on paper, but no one is guaranteed anything. If you are not interested in being a shareholder, there are other places you should probably look for a job.  Few frills. Fluid management structure. Since the company is public, it is possible that a particular persons stock options will not be immediately valuable due to market fluctuations. 
Management is frugal in spending, so don't expect lots of trips to Europe in first class at top rated hotels for junkets.

pros:
Great technology
customers are typically happy with vmware
no lack of sales activity
vmware still a buzz word company with customers
cons:
almost no promotions within the company - most hires from outside - great culture has become too diluted.
turnover increasing.
morale going down across the board.
technology innovation stalling - OEMing more technology from other companies.
internal sales tools are brittle.
most customers have purchased their core technologies - concerns over future lines of revenue
too many version 1.0 products - new products do not scale to the levels needed (or expected by customers).
Reward risks - Presidents club for sales cancelled after the end of the year and after winners had been announced
Sales organization divided into 2 branches (Enterprise and Commercial) causing large amounts of internal conflict due to no formal, enforced rules (customer assignments and sales achievement).
No feeling like we're "one team" anymore.

pros: Flexible, Challenging, Rewarding, Autonomous, Potential for Impact, Visibility, Respect, Team Oriented, Fiscally responsible, aggressive, encouraging, technically aggressive and on the cutting edge of technology, remaining motivated to maintain market position and continue to develop new and emerging products that solve business issues for our customers.
cons: They could use some work on back end systems/reporting/applications, etc.  With as fast as we are growing it is hard to keep up with the explosive growth.  On-boarding was a bit of a "welcome to VMware" and then off you go into the Abyss of work.  But highly functional, motivated, experienced consultants should have no problem maintaining motivation and quickly get up to speed and find the right people to reach out to.

review_title: It was just "OKAY", as it's still functions as a Start-up and competitors can easily overtake them
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
- Great work and Technology
- Great products and good learning
cons:
- Poor management in India, as Managers are WELL settled and are allowed for Internal transfers, NO matter what projects/programs they screwed-up earlier and what their earlier Survey reports or appraisals are!!!! They should be allowed to go thru reviews from existing reportees before being allowed for internal transfer to assess their performance. They just want to spend life at VMware because of their lots of RSU's!!!!
- management at India have well established with PA counter-part and can win over talks and get the work done, which is NOT at ALL sufficient to survive, Sustain and to Prove the abilities of India team and Indians!!!!
- India team and management need to work and ACT on their managers and STOP the loosing (or Drain)  Talent of over 5 years which is loosing for bad management.

pros: Good people to work with.  Management tries to be balanced. Some people don't like the increased emphasis on using a software  life cycle structure, but it's actually a good thing.
cons: Product marketing and exec management can't or don't always make the tough decisions on product direction.

review_title: Not a pleasant place to work, avoid at all costs
pros:
-Free coffee and tea
-Great workout facility in basement of building
-Lots of young people so its easy to make friends
-Amazing holiday party
-Good office location near restaurants and shopping
cons: Micromanagement is encouraged and runs rampant, leading to extreme inefficiencies for most departments at AirWatch. Work life balance does not exist, and employees are encouraged to work weekends and 12 hour+ days without any extra benefit. Certain employees are shown preferential treatment based on personal relationships, and there is no opportunity to work from home. Salary and PTO is below average, and the employee evaluation process is a joke. Most managers are promoted simply based on tenure and have no leadership experience. There is a lack of communication company wide and managers are offered no feedback on performance. There are no opportunities for upward mobility unless you are working 80+ hours a week and working hours are set in stone (no flexibility for working hours).

review_title: A one year long training ground
pros:
- Many young fresh grads. 
- Big name company in the region (VMware)
- Friendly coworkers
cons:
- No fast track. Unclear career path.
- The organization structure is mostly flat. You seldom move up; rather, you move to a different entry level position.
- No clear designation of job titles. You might be hired for a specific position; simply to have your title changed by the company to something else after you join. 
- Zero support for employee development.
- Managers do not work with each others. Each manager has his/her own political agenda. 
- Lower than average salary
- Crude products. Managers continue to emphasize qualities, but only verbally.
- The company always tout about the Trade Floor as an open and collaborative environment. Google trade floor and AirWatch. Anyone will tell you that you work in a factory farm, sweat shop or something. I see it as a major distraction. How do you expect people to work when others come over every 5 min.  If it is such a great environment, why isn't the CEO working on the Trad Floor?
- Many more that might not be safe to disclose.

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: - Engineers - still some of the best I've worked
cons:
Management bloat. All brought on board in the last couple of years. 

This used to be a place run by engineers. These days, it's run by middle management. Most of them utterly incompetent. There used to be like 2 Product Managers for each product category. Now it's more like 20 of them. All of them egotistical maniacs, more interested in getting on their soap box and telling you what their vision of the world is than in working with you. Engineering managers are no exception. They seem to care more about their own well being than of the people below them. Things like process and protocol and often held in higher regard than the product itself.

Old timers will completely vest in a couple of years. You can expect some massive engineering hemorrhage then (if not sooner), if things carry on the way they are.

pros: VMware still employs some of the best brains in the computer industry. Many have left over the last one year. Of the ones who remain, their company makes VMware a worthwhile place to stay back and learn.
cons:
Management has changed over the past two years. As a start-up and as a small company, VMware fostered an environment of growth, exchange of ideas and innovation. This, along with an able and technologically sound leadership, had driven VMware to grow from a small start-up to a technologically rich company.

The current management has, over time, engendered an opaque management system, devoid of transparency and is "process oriented". This unfortunately is hindering engineering-driven technological innovation and growth and implementation of new ideas, which in the past, have propelled VMware to success. The current management is resting on the laurels of past success without giving due credit to past management systems and the culture of openness of thought between employees and management.

Other points:

 * increasing politics in middle management
 * increasing "process oriented" management
 * no formal promotion and career growth policies
 * dwindling morale amongst employees
 * loss of faith in management

review_title: It is what you make of it, and I still love it
pros: The AirWatch office in MK is one of the coolest and nicest places you could work for in the area. Banter, fun, professionalism, impact, technology leadership, market demand, nice people, happy days
cons: There are some of the old folks sticking around who missed out on the big payday when VMW took over, disgruntled people posting irritating opinions, and whilst those folks may be disgruntled for a reason - those reasons are in the history of airwatch. Or they simply ruined their relationship to the mgmt and wonder why they're disregarded. Personally i had a fantastic 3 years and i would always do it again.

review_title: I would like to have liked VMware; it seems like it would have been a great place to work just a few years ago.
job_title: Staff Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Company has an impressive and distinguished history

- Core technologies and many of the people who work on them are very impressive

- Good benefits.
cons:
- Lots of very poor middle management.

- A questionable tier of executive management lies between the CEO and the rest of the company.

- Many ill conceived, floundering junk projects.

- Outside the core cash cow businesses, other initiatives are often questionable either technically, or from a business standpoint, or both.

- Engineering morale is poor in many groups and seems to be continuing to deteriorate.

- Worrisome attrition in multiple parts of the company.

- Salaries compare poorly with those of peer companies.

review_title: VMware is a huge software development company where it can be hard not to feel like a cog in the machine.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Great campus and benefits.
There are a lot of really smart people here.
Pay was more than adequate.
There are a lot of different projects so you can move around to new things.
cons:
This is a really big group of developers and it's hard not to feel overwhelmed by the bureaucracy and complexity of the products and organizations.  
Be prepared to be re-organized about every 6 months.  VMware has some significant growing pains and isn't always effective at using all the talent they've hired.
Much of the work is re-active and not pro-active.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Colleagues/peers are great - friendly and knowledgeable.  Product Development and Product Marketing colleagues are smart and strategic.
cons:
New management - promoted from within are very poor at managing people and are VERY unprofessional.  I saw people "chewed' out in front of other colleagues.  No training for new employees and contractors.  Very high pressure environment with very little support from anyone except your colleagues.

Internal managers in partner enablement and other departments think they know about partner management and sales but they do not.  "White tower" mentality here and it is hurting VMware.

review_title: Lot of potential but toxic work environment and a non functional HR team
pros: Young and dynamic organization with opportunity to work with the best in business
cons: India (Bangalore) office is full of dirty politics. Operations teams are treated like dirt with only R&D being given importance. OPs managers haven't got a clue and you survive and grow only if you are their friend. Horrible recruitment policy with rules/criteria being bent as a manager wishes and the HR team is almost invisible. NO employee handbook even after so many years in existence tells you the story. Toxic work atmosphere where you would never want to work.

review_title: Not as great as it used to be... but still good.
pros: Great pay, cutting edge technology, flexible work environment, ability to help customers do what's right for their environment - these are the primary reasons I stay at VMware.
cons: Middle management bloat has gotten far to large (and getting larger).  Work-life balance is strained in the name if making the next sale. EMC culture is being assimilated into VMware making it less like a cutting edge startup and more like the gargantuan storage company. This isn't good for the majority that came to VMware because of it's size, flexibility and work-life opportunities.

pros: Nice Campus, Nice food perks. Good salary for newcomers.
cons: No support for real change. This company needs to grow up.  Back Office, IT addicted to Triage and Heroism rather than planning.  Disfunction in leadership, or lack thereof. Lots of Long term employees - this has been their only job.  Protecting what staff know rather than supporting and helping new staff to help the company scale.  People are disposable.  If you don't fit right away i.e. subscribe to the existing politics, you are OUT.

pros: If you are looking for a company that is energetic and you are willing to work hard, this is the place. Nothing will be handed to you, you have to earn it. The solution they are selling is the best in the industry, the best part is the people believe it. The company will continue to grow with the VMware acquisition.
cons:
Salary is far below industry standard
PTO is weak
Health Insurance is weak

review_title: Company is good but there is a lot of restriction when it comes to boundary less leadership.

poor management only with few people in India, They do group politics if you dont aligned with them, they will isolate you and you wont get much hike. they create false allegation related to work and same forward to higher management.   
If you do right things though they do something to make it wrong and then blame you. No proper ownership everything driven by useless Staff or senior engineer.

when I ask some question related to technical, Staff always says, I dont know context. haha so funny, are you looking for Staff role, this is just politics. grow up.

Review once when making someone Staff or manager and takes feedback from the team without disclosing. If team gives positive then promote else never. People are doing mesh who staying from couple of years.(Not all only few)

review_title: Smart People, Lots to Learn, Be prepared for long work hours if you wish to grow.
pros: Smartest people you might have ever worked this closely with mainly because of less red-tape (yet). Highly energetic work environment because of this. Startup culture is still maintained so you can learn a lot about different things.

review_title: Still growing up, but heading in the right direction
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Cambridge, MA
pros: The current leadership is doing a pretty good job of dragging the company in the directions it needs to go in order to succeed as a modern software company.  The facilities are excellent and the benefits comparable to the rest of the industry.  Salaries and bonuses are extremely good compared to mature software companies.
cons: VMware is still learning how to be a globally distributed software company.  Many of its processes suited it well when it was 100 academicians working in Palo Alto, but communication and collaboration have not kept pace with the explosive employee growth.  The company's product development process seems very bureaucratic and the result is many products taking years to come to fruition.

pros:
Good starting pay and benefits
Great people (piers)
Nice campus
Global interaction
VMware has had some changes and is not the same company but the technology is fantastic
cons:
VMware has had some changes and is not the same company
No work life balance
No advancement seriously you cannot move between groups without permission from your current manager, you cannot advance up word in other groups the move must be lateral, these are policy.
Top Heavy and balloted – Inverted Pyramid theory from Business 101
Employees are expected to get it done at any personal cost. 
Mid management is afraid to push back on dates even if this means product delivery dates due to a bug fest.
The tail wages the dog (Marketing being the tail)

pros: Good office facilities, cafe and beverages, snacks - these are constantly the same so at one point you no longer like them. The opportunity to work with smart engineers (emphasize on engineers, because not all managers are like that) using latest technologies.
cons: There are few hypocrite managers which believe they can "influence" all other with their incorrect behavior. The opportunities for promotion are not equal to all employees - there are few employees who are regularly promoted - let's say every 2 years without any strong justification for that. At the same time people with strong technical contribution are intentionally stuck on low levels and eventually smart engineers either leave the company or are managed by inadequate "fast-promoted" managers which actually devalues the process. The situation in Bulgarian office unfortunately is as in the whole Bulgaria -not transparent, corrupted, "friends-only" fake promotions.

review_title: Constantly evolving, sometimes frustrating, but ultimately awesome
pros: The best thing about VMware in my opinion is that they are willing to invest in their employees. Rather than force you to hop jobs as is done so frequently in the Valley, VMware is much more willing to promote from within. There is a strong base of VMware "lifers" who are the pillars of the internal management team, and there is mentorship and success to be had if you have the right attitude. Work/life balance is excellent.
cons: VMware has had a little too much "evolving" going on lately. Large scale and poorly planned shakeups have left some disillusioned or feeling rudderless. While this is hopefully all behind us, having seen major reorganizations happen several times in my tenure I do worry that it may continue.

review_title: One of the best places to work in Silicon Valley
pros:
-Very smart employees
-Truly collaborative culture, you can approach nearly anyone and if you are competent, you will be welcomed with open arms
-In my group, caring and inclusive management team
-Excellent team work and camaraderie 
-People are happy here
-Work life balance is the best I have seen; don't get me wrong, we work hard, but people know when to unplug.
cons:
-As mentioned by others, the company's grown so fast, there seems to be some duplication and redundancy in work done across several organizations
-Mid-Level (Managers to Sr. Directors) could use training in how to encourage and develop employees.  Difference at VMW, this is recognized and discussed.  There are programs being kicked off to help managers learn how to be effective leaders.  I have not seen this in similar companies in my 20+years in the Valley.

review_title: Nice campus and pay | Not-so-interesting product roadmap | Some engineering teams do not code
job_title: Member of Technical Staff III in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Pioneers of cloud software, it is THE company if you are a cloud computing enthusiast
- Pretty good campus
- Best place for systems engineering
- You'll get to learn lots of low level stuff
- Good pay
- Nice events - Friday bashes, VMware unplugged, RADIO(limited admission) & VMWorld
- Voice of VMware - A survey where you'll get to anonymously review your boss which is really great
cons:
- Be careful about the org you join, coz, some teams don't write significant code and all they do is things like bug triaging etc, which can be quite dangerous if you are a developer at heart
- Some managers tend to nag the employees and some don't even give a sh*t and just slack off, both are not good
- After couple of years, work can get routine and boring

pros: Lots of great people who want to do the right thing and are passionate about winning in their market.  Compelling solutions that customers are adopting broadly.  Employees are empowered to build plans and execute.
cons: Many transitions happening at the company at once - employees are struggling to feel informed and certain about the future. Not clear what impact will be of Dell acquisition, recent leadership changes, market transitions around shift to cloud and lack of clarity on what role VMware will play. Leadership does not all appear to aligned and in lock step going forward about how the company will navigate all these transitions.  Work pace is very fast - challenge is that everyone is dealing with what is urgent, not what is strategic...

review_title: Like a boxing fight, you need to be tough too survive the battle!
job_title: Enterprise Account Executive in Milton Keynes, England
pros: Great product, amazing talent but this is changing. Unfortunately it is on the verge to loose all top talents. Run by a MD who thinks he is the greatest of all.
cons:
No need to say much, they know exactly where to start.

review_title: CPD team is completely customer care, no technical learnings
job_title: Software Engineer (Member Technical Staff) in Bangalore

cons:
No growth in organization who works well during the working hours
Engineers and Managers work only for recognition rather than self learning

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: VMware has a relatively high base salary plus some other perks, but over the years the RSU is shrinking to almost nothing.
cons:
Bad management level,  many managers don't even understand the project his group is doing. Most of the time, they just attend meetings,  inquire engineers about some very basic concepts, pass messages and push people to fix bugs, meet deadlines and ask for more resources, that is it.   No product vision, don't know how to allocate people and resources to get the job done.  They only care about their promotions or keep the job, not the engineers.

In VMware, if one is not technical, doesn't know programming, doesn't know how to manage people, but knows how to play politics. He must be a manager.

review_title: Poor communications & planning - Only care about making the number
pros: Great technology and most of the products are tops.  Great internal website and great individual people.  Still a very can do attitude within the company
cons: The company only cares about making the quarterly sales target.  Little desire to do the right thing by the customer.  Customer service is an after thought.  The overall processes within the company are disjointed, not well thought out.  Very poor planning with little thought of the consequences.  Management style is "Do it my way" or hit the highway.  There is no reward for resolving process issues and making the company more efficient.  Everything is goaled according th the number.

pros: Environment within CPD (bug-fixing) teams is excellent and people are highly skilled and qualified. When a critical issue comes, you can easily get help from teams across domains (from core kernel, file-system to storage) to get it resolved.
cons: If you enter CPD stream, there is almost no way to enter product aka core development work. You will be forced to work exclusively on just bug-fixing and no opportunity is available in terms of time and other resources for more creative work. Even communication with core teams to solve an issue is considered as "taking their help" which counts negatively for you.

pros: The technology is rock solid!  There are many great people to work with. Lots of opportunity.  Benefits are ok.  They get the cloud better than many other companies. Many opportunities for advancement--they keep acquiring more companies. Several senior leaders are amazing.
cons: EMC influence drives politics that are not employee friendly.  Many unhappy people working at VMW. I saw a few great people get stuck in lower level positions because someone at the top had heard and listned to gossip rather than providing opportunities and giving people a chance.

review_title: If I had to do it all over again, I'd still work here as long as I did. I would just avoid any contact with HR.
pros:
Super smart people in all organizations. Really good products.

Great benefits.

Good training, but needs to scale to be as powerful as an organization of our current size.
cons:
If you don't work out of the Palo Alto campus, you won't get all the great perks like free concerts and beer bashes.

Too many upper management/executive hires in the past few years have turned this into EMC, which is detrimental innovation and independence.

If you have to work directly with HR, I have found that without exception, they are the most horrible, uncaring people on the planet. In hiring, onboarding, and other employment tasks, they have offered no value, hindering the process and making it a terrible experience for the employee and manager. I don't know how true that is for other large companies.

review_title: Cork is turning itself into a Call Center
job_title: Senior Technical Support Engineer in Ballincollig
pros:
Good compensation (if you negotiate your salary during the job interview, or else, you'll be stuck)
Possibility to travel to US or Europe
Looks good on CV
cons:
The center has seen a  lot of people leaving but currently it's unable to hire good ones (brain drain with only WPPs being hired).
People are leaving because they are underpaid or they found something more interesting to do.
The place wast turned upside down with the big focus on metrics and Csats. A TSE is someone who has to take calls, close a minimum of x cases per day and at the end of the day, will also have to keep customers happy (while most of times there is no proper training for new or existing products). Feels like working on a factory.
Company has a multi-cultural environment but 95% of the management is Irish.

review_title: Strong technology strategy, lacking in sales & marketing strategy
pros: Starts with the products - customers love VMware's products - one of the best ROI stories for core virtualization that exists in enterprise software space.  Great campus/working environment - little quiet but can't beat being in the Stanford Research Park if you are going to work in Silicon Valley.  Very good work-life balance - people clear out between 5:00 - 6:00pm - could run naked through campus  at 6:00 and don't think you would run into anyone.
cons: Although we have great technology, our sales and marketing engine does not measure up to the product side of the house.  So intently focused on 90 day/quarterly results that little thought is given to how we should be marketing and selling our offerings 2 years down the line.  Accountability is lacking in sales groups.

review_title: great past, uncertain future, high potential
pros: Self-starter culture, plenty of day to day empowerment, huge customer base with very positive relationship, above average salary and benefits, lots of believers.
cons: Culture- some areas approach things like sales and R&D in the same virtualization-focused mindset that worked 6 years ago, but the current market needs a more solution-focused approach, rapid iteration and strong link to business value. This mindset is often found in the people that have been here the longest and have had great success in the past, putting them in positions of influence, making it tough to shift.

pros: great technology and solutions, great people
cons: The very best health plan offered at VMware is the Aetna with a pre-paid Health Equity account.  Having a family with kids that play sports, we end up at the ER often in addition to the typical Dr visits.  Aetna covers about 30-50% of claims.  In addition to the low coverage, it is very administrative to login to the Health Equity website and match the claims (which is a mystery as the $ amounts don't match) and then fund them with your equity account.  It is also very unclear which is which.  I was told that moving away from the HMO was voted on by employees.  I was never presented with a voting option.   It would be great if VMware could bring back an HMO as an option for employees.  Upon inquiring about this I was told that VMware cannot absorb the costs of an HMO.  Hoping this changes.

review_title: VMware is a good balance between the craziness of a startup and the stability of a large company like Oracle.

review_title: While it boasts a friendly work-environment, VMware ignores individual accomplishments, rewarding only mass success.
job_title: Support Staff in Palo Alto, CA
pros: I supppose the best reasons for working at VMware would be for the benefits; the stock options, a really cool, new "Green" campus, the buzz of working for a semi-public start-up software company, interesting people, medical, dental and life insurance...etc.

Oh there are so many downsides, how can I list all of them?
If you are part of the "working force" (i.e. not an engineer, sales-person, or marketing tech) you are NOBODY.  No matter how many times you confront HR or your supervisor/manager, you never feel a sense of worth.  Loyalty is not taken into consideration, dedication is not a factor.  You can be with the company for years, and never see appreciation in any tangible form.

pros: People in R&D are really terrific.  The overall engineering team is filled with talent and energy, sincerity, and passion.  Many front line and middle managers are trying really hard to do the right thing.  Campus is awesome, reallly earth friendly, terrific environment from that regards.

A lot of senior managers have come in over the last two years from failing software companies and have brought their people with them, in some cases entire departments at the cost of some long time dedicated VMware people.  Silos exist everywhere and there is no accountability for internal programs or projects.  HR can never get anything done.  Just completed annual reviews and many people never got a meeting with their managers.  Annual pay increases were late, arrived today and many many people received nothing.  This will be two years for alot of people who did not get pay increases.

pros: Structured process, well defined and easy to focus on selling as there is lots of support teams to help drive sales deals
cons:
Majority of leaders are more focussed managing up the food chain than looking after employees 
Expensive products against some of the competitors, and they dont seem to be evalgalising the technology only buying out new companies with the hope they return to where they were in 2007! 
Dell buyout was a business decision but VMware would have been a much better business had they backed themselves quicker to growth than tagging with Dell who are archaic at best! 
Focus on the customer. Half of what I sold was put into the deal that was never required but really expensive. Be truthful - put customer first for once instead of pocket

job_title: Software Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: VMware has provided for a stable job so far and the compensation seems to be at least on par with other companies.  For the most part, the employees are friendly and pleasant to work with.  Overall the company seems to be holding a reasonable course and should continue to be successful for some time to come.  For the most part, you are given some flexibility in finding work that interests you.
cons: The company has grown way too fast.  The fast growth has allowed mediocre employees to excel in all the confusion.  Sometimes there is a lot of chaos.  Often there is a disconnect between management and engineers.  The headquarters is located in a boring office park.

review_title: Fantastic place for a long term career
job_title: Solutions Architect in Palo Alto, CA
pros: All VMware offices around the world are similar: Spotless, efficient, and with heathy refreshments always available.  The Management team in my department were fantastic.  Expect to work hard and be rewarded and recognized for your accomplishments. While I was hired directly into VMware, I worked with a number of people coming in from acquisitions.  Those coming onboard through the M&A process can expect a few process bumps, but you will be part of the VMware family on day one.  Best path to success for anyone at this company is to be fluid and flexible - never a dull moment at VMware.
cons: There aren't many. The few issues I ran into are common across all moderately sized companies going through rapid growth and M&A activities.

pros: VMware Bulgaria is one of the top choices in the country for career development and innovation. It offers a variety of positions and caters to people's aspirations for growth. The pay is competitive and the benefits are great. Depending on your team, you have Agile processes and choose your own tasks. Amazing work/life balance that allows you to stay only a few hours if you can complete your tasks fast, or stay overtime if you are swarmed. You can work from home, working hours are floating (some people come at 14:00h, some leave at 15:00h etc.).
cons: Depending on the team that you join, you might face horrible processes (not all teams have Scrum), you might be pigeonholed into fixing bugs or do tasks that are not to your liking. So there is a bit of RNG and you hope for the best.

pros: Almost 2 years into my employment at Glassdoor and I've decided the excitement of working here isn't a phase. I love the management, they encourage employees to grow and learn with the company. And as fast as I've seen things go I've learned just as much if not more. There is no micromanaging in my department, but rather a trust we are all working together to meet our goals.
cons: There was a time when I wasn't receiving the feedback I was hoping to improve. But this was not a short coming of management. It was a time of growth and we didn't have anyone leading our team at the time. Upper management was taking the proper lengths to make sure we got the right guy to lead our team

job_title: Senior Software Engineer (Labs) in New York, NY
pros:
- Pivotal just does everything right - they really do care for their employees and about doing the right thing. 
- Leadership is approachable and is always asking for feedback (which they act on). 
- They take D&I seriously. Whenever a leadership role opens up, an email goes out to the entire company. They state they will not close the applications for the role until at least 2 people from underrepresented backgrounds apply.  For the folks they don't select, they give constructive feedback.
cons:
None of them are cons for me, but I can imagine the top ones for most engineers would be:
- It's very 9-6.* For some engineers, this is too early or too rigid of a schedule.
- It's not super remote friendly. You can certainly work remotely sometimes, but if that's a big part of your current lifestyle, that would be hard to maintain.
- You pair 100% of the time.

* Varies by office. Some offices do 8-5, etc.

review_title: A disappointing time at a company with an admirable history
pros:
Nice campus.

In VMware's core strong businesses, there are some extremely strong engineers and technologists, who have built amazing things.
 
The current CEO, Paul Maritz, speaks well, and seems to have a decent view of the industry.
cons:
VMware's core virtualization business will eventually commoditize.  How long that can be kept at bay before painful financial impact is felt is unclear.

Outside of the core technology teams, VMware is littered with junk projects, appallingly weak middle (and even some upper) management and a general lack of coherent mission.

It's unclear that much of the clarity that seems to exist in Maritz's mind is making it through and past the burgeoning layer of VPs between him and the part of the company that actually builds and sells things.

Attrition seems bad:  lots of senior and upper-mid-level technical folks are leaving.  Some are old-timers who helped build VMware into what it is today, while others are moving on after tenures of only one or two years.

review_title: Fast paced work, aggressive deadlines and very bright, motivated employees
job_title: Senior Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: It's an exciting place to be and I love working with 'A players' in the industry.  People are smart and motivated, which has meant that we are able to retain great talent.  I have been at the company for 5 years and VMware has consistently grown and been profitable - even through a very rough economic climate.  I attribute that success and vision to the executive leadership.
cons: VMware will suck the life out of you if you let it.  Work / life balance is a constant struggle.  The pay is not as competitive as other companies.  Working in 5th gear all of the time gets exhausting.

review_title: Fun place to be with, innovative company. This company is growing in the mobile device management and does not compare
job_title: Applications Support Engineer in Atlanta, GA
pros: If you are a motivated software developer person and can grow a book of business with a great company culture - this is the place to do it. Yes many prospects are taken but if you are creative and willing to put in some additional effort, you can make six-figure earnings within the first 3 years.
cons: Indeed is a good company. Its success and growth have been increasing dramatically - YOY numbers are pretty crazy. It is highly unlikely that you'll ever experience a start up gain such success again. It's pretty amazing to see, and honestly, pretty fun to be a part of.

job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Overall, the culture is one of co-operation.  Certainly, within teams everyone helps each other.   Most people I meet are friendly.  Working for a growing, profitable company means good bonuses and hope that stock options will remain valuable.
cons:
While most people are friendly, there are a number of engineers that don't know how to communicate.  Yes, this is true in many companies, however the ones I'm thinking of are in highly senior positions.  They may be right most of the time in their judgements, but how they express themselves can make the work place feel hostile.
The fast growth and slow learning (the products are complex) can make for a frustrating environment at times.  Especially when it's difficult to find someone who knows the origins of some module.   The fast growth also brought in some low talent engineers and managers.

pros: Good values, good people. Innovation is not just a slogan.
cons:
Coding standards vary between teams dramatically.

Very high demands. Management became posh and pompous. Demands are high, but benefits don't match. 

Lots of people from Mercury came in to manage. People got higher in rank due to personal relationships (friends from previous workplace).

No investment/ lacking investment in future development of staff. No courses. Nothing organized for the people.
Site budget got lower, despite the site growing larger. Day to day benefits reduced.

job_title: Staff Architect in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Very good work/life balance. Salary and benefits are also good at VMware. It's great for people with families/kids as there are many activities on a nice campus in Palo Alto.
cons:
Lack of professional/technical growth, but also lack of advancement or growth opportunities within your career.  
A lot of manager in middle management were bad engineers and got promoted to where they can't do much damage. But without proper training they end up being bad managers as well.
Experience is very specific to a team with some of the teams having some really incompetent engineers. Processes are broken, don't exist at all, are very antiquated and worst of all: resistant to change.
Customers are becoming increasingly dissatisfied with even the core products.

job_title: Product Line Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Good people, intelligent, motivated, sincere. Great collaborative culture where you can approach almost anyone in the company. Innovation is encouraged and people and groups are empowered to do so. Schedule flexibility and good work life balance, but you'll still work very hard (and enjoy it).
cons: The empowerment of people and groups to innovate leads to duplication of effort sometimes. Some people have been in the company too long for their own good and are outdated. The company has traditionally been one level removed from hardware, and it is making the efforts to change to be more lean and agile, but change is painful and changing people's mindsets takes time. For anything other than AirWatch, you will need to be in Palo Alto. The core of VMware does not do well with a distributed environment. The San Francisco office shrunk as VMware gave up the better half of the floor.

job_title: Senior Solutions Architect in Farmers Branch, TX
pros:
Working for VMware is and has been a fantastic experience. Somehow, VMware with 25k employees (Family members) manages to treat us as individuals versus as a number. VMware heavily invests in you and your professional and personal growth.
VMware created a family-style work environment where everyone is approachable and easy to talk too; this includes upper management.
cons:
No company is without faults; however, I calculate the pros and cons and conclude that VMware is a fantastic company. Sure one could nitpick.
Not a con but does add to work stress - Since VMware's inspection, they have been paving the way forward by creating new paths and leading the industry and our customers to new heights. Today, VMware continues to push and challenge the status quo through further developments and acquisitions. Sometimes it feels like you are changing a flat tire at 200 mph.

But as it is a fast growing company one is given an opportunity to grow based on performance.

pros:

review_title: VMware's one of the best companies in the Valley to work for.

If you're not working out of the Palo Alto or San Francisco offices, you may experience some random pain from time to time (for example, the link to the primary RCS servers running in Palo Alto might randomly not be as speedy as you'd like all the time).

Employees are trusted to organize their time efficiently. Great collaboration and opportunities. Worked here years ago, and was delighted to get the chance to come back 2 years ago. Would not want to leave.

review_title: Nice technology and very nice campus

Departmental politics hurt VMware because they foster a culture where those who invest long hours in office politics are rewarded rather than the innovaters, team players and hard workers.

review_title: Fantastic technology that is easy to sell let down by over complex processes and continual change
pros: If you want to work somewhere where the growth rates of the business are phenomenal, then look no further. The appetite for VMware's core technology by both partners and customers alike is overwhelming. A wonderful brand name and thought leadership from the senior management team make it an attractive place to be.
cons: The rapid growth has led to a number of problems of scaling. In terms of process and market coverage they find it hard to keep up. This leaves the "middle management" with a the tough role of trying to make do and also the pressure of the expected growth can sometimes lead to confusing decisions.

review_title: Great technology, but not a great to work!
pros:
Great technology
Definitely one of the most visionary CEOs in the industry
Great under valued people in the field that put in all the work e.g. SEs, PSCs, TAMs
Great training on VMware products is easily available
cons:
Acquisition is occurring at a very fast rate with little to no near term integration, make it very difficult to talk about products outside of the core product and paint an integrated story. The company seems to be VERY worried about Microsoft.
Career advancement is very limited.
The majority of mid-level to senior-level management within the Reston office are ex-EMC from the old EMC. The have brought over the unhappy work culture with them.
Comp plans change half way through the year and are getting tighter and tighter.

review_title: A massive change towards discouraging, limiting possibilities, caused by non-visionaire average managers.
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Ballincollig
pros: VMware still is the market leader for virtualization - but that's about it.
cons:
- worst call centre experience ever,  after a startup mood and empowering in the past things have changed towards metrics only. Visions and ideas are suppressed and not followed upon you report into a black hole and get no feedback unless you ping a VP or senior director directly.

- wording to be used dictated, no freedom of speech, no adoption to customer needs, improvement suggestions land in a back hole.

- the Vision and spirit in this company is gone

- workers are currently approaching unions about conditions

- It still pays of get intimate with leaders, in order to progress in ones career

review_title: Great Place to Work - if You're Director or Above
pros: Smart people, great technology, beautiful campus, good benefits.
cons: VPs and Directors are dictatorial and arrogant. Revolving door at the VP level and endless re-orgs - new executives bring their entourages with them. They clog middle management and dilute the culture. If you have ideas, experience, and career ambitions you will be frustrated at VMware. Unless you sit at the Director-level or above, you can't get involved in discussions that affect your future. You will be told what to do - and if you don't like it, you will have to find another job.

review_title: Great experience during the growth years
job_title: Senior Sales Engineer in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Opportunity to really see the entire IT ecosystem as a central participant.  Opportunities to participate in new initiatives and markets.  Pay is very good.  Engineers are some of the best.
cons:
As with any large company, internal politics limits what can be achieved.  Customer is not as important as what the engineering team "wants to do".  Very difficult to do internal transfers -- my opportunities came only when management offered them on their own after rebuffing my own attempts.  Still worked out, but process wasn't pleasant.

I noticed a rating on "work/life balance" below.  There is none.  Get over it -- they are paying you really well.  And if you don't get an awesome offer, don't take the job.

pros: Nice and helpful peers; Resourceful IT support; company sales performance is crazy good. Highest C level people are fantastic both Airwatch and VMWare the parent company. Good pay. Probably good place to start up for new grad or new in the market.
cons: I agree with another review that individuals in mid management really makes the place terrible; for a company this size this project is disoriented and vision is confusing. There's not much to gain from this place if you have more than several years of experience. Treat employee sub-par compares to most other tech companies.

pros: Having recently joined from a less mature organisation, the culture is truly refreshing - lots of respect for the individual, great work to break down silos of operations and simply one of the most relevant customer conversations to be having at this time
cons:
I'm not sure they understand the size of the opportunity in the field - don't be an engineering company with a hidden message.  

It's now a value sale, not a widget you just need - the solution portfolio is amazing, it needs to tell the customers and not stay in product silo's

review_title: VMware is a great place to work
job_title: Marketing Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Great technology - virtualization benefits anyone who uses a computer which is pretty much everyone in the world.  Virtualization is all about reducing cost and energy and who wouldn't want that!
Great culture - we work hard and we play hard.  It's always tough balancing your work and life but if you have the support from management and they respect that you do have a life outside of work, then it just makes a bit easier to juggle both.  
Smart people - I've met some of the smartest people here at VMware and being around such smart people makes your job so much easier!
cons: Company is growing at a very fast pace and the necessary support infrastructure is still in the catch up phase.

review_title: Good company in the midst of a painful reorganization.
job_title: Program Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
VMWare can be an excellent plance to work:  there are many excellent people to work with, the products are exciting, the campus is beautiful, and for many jobs telecommuniting is possible (indeed, required) since the workforce is spread across the globe.  Depending upon one's immediate supervisor, one's time requirements can be very flexible.  Some people telecommute every day, others come to the office every day, and others negotiate other arrangements, i.e. coming in to the office one or more days a week or as required to attend specific meetings.

VMWare is going through a major top-down reorganization which should result in a more efficiently run and successful company.
cons: Unfortunately, because of the reorganization, which is still in progress, chaos often reigns.

review_title: Apart from the software, there is no vision
pros:
Working with cutting edge technology, on the fore front of virtualisation efforts, great and large projects for customers, all make it worthwhile to work for VMware.

Even in this economic climate we can travel to all parts of EMEA for projects.
cons:
Very little strong leadership. HR treats employees like we should be glad to work for VMware.
Very bad resource management. A lot of projects and still people have a low billable utilisation.

Too many management layers!

Benefits are being cut in certain areas and we're told we're lucky to have a job.

review_title: Dynamic environment with huge knowledge base (if you know how to tap into it)
pros:
Free trainings and certifications
Good salary (if you hit it off well during hiring process)
Snacks and coffee for free
Hard work = promotions
Easy access to huge knowledge base, source codes, etc. - if you know where to look for (and what to look for)
cons:
Workload doesn't leave much time for self development
Lots of experienced people left and took valuable knowledge with them - feels like management isn't even trying to keep them.
Salary doesn't increase with time, experience or performance
Product complexity is increasing rapidly - inadequate training provided to the support engineers

pros: Great company atmosphere, Great people, Forever evolving and fast paced
cons: Not great at getting support from management, very much go sort it yourself attitude. Very Cut Throat and Pressure Sales ethos now being administered throughout. Losing the great atmosphere that the company has been renowned for since the begining, since the takeover it has been a backwards step in changing RTM (more channel focused) when we were so successful and in control of business being direct RTM. Too much process and red tape to get business processed, Making one of our USP's in the ease and accessibility to customers and partners in transacting alot more stressful.

pros:
Lots of growth, lots of opportunity, business as usual is a rare thing, always something to work on improve/overhaul due to the pace of the business and the expansion of products and volume of business.
Flexible working is generally accepted and encouraged where it makes sense for your role.
Successful, profitable company where bonuses are good and rewards fair. For me it was a great place to be for most of my time at VMware.
cons:
Can be high pressure. The recent changes at E -1/-2 level have brought more politics into the organisation.
The EPIC2 values are rarely demonstrated by those just below E-staff. There is little effort to redeploy or retrain long serving employees. Staff are fairly disposable.

job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Burlington, ON
pros: They treat employees well at VMware. With free, snacks, lunches, drinks. Awesome health benefits, etc. The environment among support is very friendly and co-operative.
cons: Over the years since the company has gotten very top heavy with way too much management. They micromanage and interfere with supports work all the while not fixing any of the core company problems like being short staffed and over worked with case average per TSE climbing.

review_title: Great products, employees and campus. Older leaders to political, newer to removed, so losing strong mojo
job_title: Senior Director in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Great products and working environment, campus is beautiful. Trying to find next engine of growth, so some fear of slowing growth and layoffs. Potential spin off from EMC in offing.  Employees are some of the best and brightest, but starting to leave
cons: Some older leaders are too political to hold onto power, many new are from much larger companies and are very aloof and removed. So company losing it's leadership edge and becoming less inspiring.

review_title: Great overall package and work conditions
job_title: Senior Solutions Architect in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Depending on your manager and team, it can be a great, inspiring, fresh place to work in. The Palo Alto campus is one of the best places ever although once you get in your cube, nothing is different. Benefits are matching competitor offerings. Work from home gives you less expenses and almost totally flexible working hours.
cons: Again, depending on your manager and team, it can be hell. Stay away from PSO related jobs as they will try to put you on 100% travel. Flexible working from home hours might also mean that you have conference calls from the US with Australia and / or China regularly..

job_title: Program Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Great benefits and campus
- Flex work schedule
- Compensation aligned with the industry
cons: EMC culture is seeping in at VMware. There's a "yes ma'am" mentality going on. Management can benefit from being more gracious to their employees - the expectation is to work 50+ hours a week with no thank you. High turnover within the past year.

review_title: It's not as good as it once was
pros: 2-3 years ago I would've given 5 stars across the board. VMware was very employee oriented. I bragged as often as I could about how happy I was to be a part of such an innovative company with such supportive management. Work/Life balance was a concept I had never heard of and the growth opportunities were limitless.
cons: Cash flow business model. That's the only thing that seems matters now. Not the years of hard work people have put into that company. Culture and values used to be important. Guess that's just the nature of the beast. They've really grown to embrace the devil that is Corporate America. I think it is safe to say that it won't be getting better any time soon.

review_title: Great place to learn Virtualization and getting paid for it!
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Broomfield, CO
pros: The environment is made for people being introduced into the world of virtualization. The other support engineers all have specialties and are willing to help you excel as it helps them to get you trained to help offload the overall workload for each team. You start with training that would cost over $2k per class and you take over four classes to get skilled with VMware products. Not only that, you are able to request to take other certification courses (paid for through education expenses) and they will also assist with certification exam fees.
cons: Large companies require much more effort to be recognized by management and senior management. Call center environment is open by it is slowly becoming micro managed.

review_title: Incredible technologies, brilliant people, and some growing pains
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
ESX and and the tools to manage it and leverage it (vSphere, View, etc.) are still some of the most incredible pieces of software that I've had the pleasure of working on. Extremely complex and extremely fascinating.

The internal tools at VMware are well maintained and are a huge asset to employee productivity and testing (internal cloud, etc).

Thousands of very bright engineers.

The internship program is large and very interactive; there are lots of intern-only events, a few intern-manager/mentor events, coding competitions, etc.
cons:
Lots of bandaids on top of an aging code base, where a re-design would be appropriate.

Way too many features planned for any particular release, which stretches engineering (and testing) thin and leads to bugs too late in the development cycle.

review_title: Highly Politicized Environment but good benefits
pros:
Great benefits
Good Salary
ESPP and Stock option grants
Fully stocked kitchen
Really nice gym and campus
cons:
Very, very political environment. Everybody fights for dominance and plays mind games with employees and contractors. The only way to survive is to find a "Godfather" who will protect and nurture you. 
Best survival strategy is to say "yes" to everybody with little bit of power and "no" to everybody else. 
HR uses performance reviews and ratings as a weapon to use against you when the opportunity strikes. If you align yourself with the right people, you don't need to worry about it.

pros:
Technology oriented company.
Equal opportunity employment.
Lots and Lots of opportunity to acquire new skill and work on different virtualization products
cons:
Technically handicapped and blind management in India at least (Don't know about US and other locations).
Managers sometimes put over-emphasis on filing patents and submitting white papers in order to get them noticed in front of US counterparts.They believe doing so would get them (managers) applauded by higher management in US.
Even though the initiative of  80:20 work program was started by US, the Indian employees hardly got any benefit of this because most of the time employees are burdened by the regular day to day activities.

review_title: Amazing company! Very happy to work here!
pros:
VMware is awesome! I'm so grateful to work for this company! Work-life balance is a priority and this isn't a common practice these days! Professional and personal growth are encouraged by management! 

The environment and management create a "want" to do your best! Why wouldn't you want to work hard for a company that takes care of their employees!? You really feel like part of a team!
cons: No use of a CRM or central data depository. This creates a lot of manual tracking in regards to accounting and project data.

pros: Amazing perks and benefits. You can tell the company really cares about its employees. There is clear communication and a lot of transparency. From top to bottom, you really feel aligned and connected with the company at large. It's no wonder people dedicate a good chunk of their careers at this company -- upwards of 10, 15, and 20 years, you'll find some veterans here that don't get jaded. Rather, they keep the energy alive. It's a great training ground for those just starting their career. Succeed here, take advantage of resources, find a mentor, and you'll be set to achieve wherever you end up.
cons: Can be high pressure at times, but the work culture and environment make it worth it, and even inspire you to push yourself because you know you'll feel good in the end...and the company will recognize the work you put in.

review_title: Everything you hear about VMware is true!
job_title: Consulting Architect in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Outstanding culture, technology leader. I often tell people that working at VMware is the most difficult, but also most rewarding position I've held in over 20 years. VMware won't spoon-fed you, but will ensure that you are given the tools and opportunities to go as far as you want. Your success at VMware is directly tied to your effort that you put in.
cons: Compensation is little below other technology companies in the Bay area. Some career paths, particularly those in Professional Services, have a limited path.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
You get paid very well.
You get a lot of flexibility.
cons: The politics are rampant in the company. The job I was promised (and the reason I left my old job) was clearly not what the company wanted to do and it became very clear that  I had limited options. You have to be constantly looking over your shoulder (including peers and managers) to see where the knives are. There are lots of mediocre developers and C grade managers in power. Seems the longer you are there the more you can cover up by blaming the last guy who was there.  BU structure is counter productive and creates internal battles that are just not good for the company. Being under Dell doesn't make this any easier.

review_title: It's not all fun and games
job_title: Senior Director in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Working with very smart people is an absolute pleasure. Things move at a quick pace and results are achieved quickly when all the resources are within your control.
cons:
Extremely nerdy culture - even at a Senior Management level - you are expected to be extremely technical. 
Misalignment amongst the exec team  - the exec team runs their respective functions like general managers, with little communication at the next levels.
Outwardly a polite culture, but had started to become very politically charged after 2004 - post EMC aquisition mainly due to the growth - folks started to mark out their territories, and were extremely protective of their space and teams. Some of the collaborative culture went away as a result.

review_title: Be Prepared to work long hours
pros:
1. Campus is nice.
2. Technology is very good.
3. Company is still the market leader.  Most of the server growth will be in virtual machines.
cons:
1. The company has had very high growth, but has not invested in the back-end infrastructure.  You spend all your time just trying to manually crunch data. As a result, you spend long hours doing manual work.
2. If you get along with your boss, you will do fine.  If you don't -- start looking for a new job.  There is no place to go in the company other than out.
3. The work is unevenly spread out.  Certain teams are just buried, and other teams have lots of free time to play -- ping pong etc.

pros: Fast growing, good compensation, energetic environment, culture of open sharing of information and ideas. Culture encourages new ideas and teamwork.  The CEO is a strategic genius and is taking the company in the right direction.
cons: Get all you can on the front end because this company will not promote from within and this is the reason that attrition is higher than you would expect for such a fast growing company.  The pay scale is good,  but not as competitive as other tech firms.  You will need to negotiate going in to remain whole, but it can be done if you are the top candidate.

review_title: Lots of cliques and infighting.  All the liabilities of a start up and an established company.
job_title: Global Support Services in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
flexible hours
average pay
average benefits
some ability to move between groups - assuming you can network the move ahead of time
still looks good on a resume
cons:
vision is gone
penny pinching has set in
one hour of discussions required per minute of actual work accomplished
rules by Excel spreadsheets that govern each fiefdom
no reward for loyalty - the longer you stay the more likely you'll wind up on the purge list
no training unless its on your own time

review_title: OK company - needs a regime change
pros: Open atmosphere, little micromanagement and  flexible hours in R&D. VMware's acquisition is starting to have a somewhat good impac .
cons:
Product Management department is filled with completely inexperienced people from support side. 
Company does not make money and VMware is now seeing this as well which is now resulting in cutbacks and hiring freezes across different department . 
They've hired a giant group of freshers straight out of school because they are cheap and they will do as they are told. Same formula was used at Manhattan Associates This is a good plan to capture good market share but horrible for product quality which shows in forms of bugs and hotfixes across all products.

review_title: Best company I have worked for....
pros:
I have been with 3 other tech vendors of similar size to VMware. After 4 years VMware is still the best place have worked.
I bench mark regularly  and compensation/benefits are generally excellent.
VMware is generally ok with home working and relocation.
Senior management team is mature - I haven't seen pettiness or empire building that I have seen in other companies.
First place I have worked where the HR organization is professional and innovative.
Given a lot scope in my current role.
VMware's continued growth and breadth of products keeps things interesting and means there are lots of opportunities.
cons: VMware is now a big company so the normal bureaucracy that comes with that has crept in. But although decision making can be slow at times - it is better than other places I have worked.

pros: VMware hires people with little or no IT experience on work placement schemes and train them up to become Technical Support Engineers. This has provided many people with a bright future in IT who otherwise might still be jobless.
cons: Sink or swim attitude to new hires. Overloading new hires with unfair workloads is the norm.

review_title: Excellent technology, ok culture, challenging internal systems!
pros: Great innovation, some excellent people. Depending on which part of the organisation you work in it could be brilliant, I'd certainly recommend SE or sales roles especially NSX or Global... however the maturity level of most "back office" functions is on the left side of the scale so approach with caution!
cons: Some areas seem to be becoming a bit of a boys club... it's more to do with who you know not your skills and experiences that will get you that promotion. People development is completely hit and miss I think partly because some people "leaders" have been elevated beyond their capabilities (and not then supported to develop) and staff turnover as a result is noticeable.

review_title: Great Company, but has no ability to make decisions
pros: People are generally great to work with and want to get the job done,  Their are perks (food, bagels, drinks daily).  Products are great and sell themselves.  Compensation is very good at VMware.
cons: Mid to senior layers of management are very territorial to a fault, which creates a challenging environment to get work done.  There are leaders that focus more on politics than getting the job done.  There is also the inability to make decisions, specifically in marketing and marketing ops functions.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
job_title: Senior Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Great engineers, a lot of smart and very talented people
- Open communication at engineer levels
- Interesting and challenge projects, sense of as part of a big thing
- Feeling of a community
cons:
- Politics all around, especially at senior management levels.
- Too much chaos at Sr. Director to VP level, causing lack of stability to build long term plan/roadmap.
- Fairness in performance evaluation and promotion.
- Brand new senior leadership not trusting front line managers and engineers.

review_title: Not worth to work. Not a good company to join, if you are innovative and having 2-3+ exp.
pros:
Nice MDM/Content-management feature. 
Nice Products.
Nice Business skill
cons:
-Don't think about appreciate if you are not Manhattan employee or if you are not in group of people.
- You wil not get valued by your work.
- Selected people will get good chance for POC and Patent.
- There are atleast 1-2 spy people inside whole team.
- Don't think about B1/H1 visa or annual award or Hackathon winner. Its all scripted.
- Worst Stat level politics, people are using "state-language" in communication.
- Worst QA, I ever seen.
- Senior QA's are crapy politician.
- They don't have value for their words and promise.

pros:
-Great benefits - low cost, excellent coverage
-The work is unparalleled in the industry. We work in the most complex environments with the biggest challenges. 
-Unlimited PTO policy
cons:
-Layers of bureaucratic mess in middle management
-Travel for PSO is very high (70-80%)
-Promotion and review process is long and has drags on for months
-No time for training - always be billing
-PTO policy cuts both ways - any time taken off counts against you when bonus time comes 
-No industry conferences, including VMworld

review_title: As many perks as uncooperative workers
pros: Great benefits, exciting technologies to work with. Being a VMware subsidiary should eventually pay off.
cons: You will see mistakes all the time, company rarely learns from them. No follow up on career advancement touted. Very uneven distribution of work load. Some work 6-7h days and others 70h weeks. Quality of products and services never ceases to suffer from approximations and mistakes, a contagious "yes we do everything" mindset and mindless footprint expansion (illusion of extra $). Severely uncooperative individuals and poor communication/coordination undermine overall capacity to execute, as confirmed in analyst reports. Current culture makes everyone look and feel awful with constant war rooms to meet overdue and broken solutions, which are a natural result of dedicating no more attention to any system than 30min meetings.

review_title: VMware hates Canada... no respect for hardwork and dedication
job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Burlington, ON
pros:
- community and charity services are encouraged... paid 40 hrs to volunteer and matching gifts 
- the teams worked well and the front-line engineers were easy to work with and helpful
cons: Senior Management (directors and VPs) lied until he last day,  prior to closing the support center... for over a year they promised and painted rosy pic of "center of excellence" and dropped the support center.  Just after shutting down the center, VMware went full swing hiring in all other support centers!!

review_title: Good company if you want to settle for life
pros:
There is not much pressure on you, hence this is a great place if you want to settle down for life. 
Too many different things to explore. 
Core computer science work will good on resume.
cons:
Work culture is not great, the average age of the company is pretty high. 
Most of the amazing research things happen in Palo Alto office, hardly anything great in Indian offices

review_title: Pros and cons like anywhere else
job_title: Senior Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
1. Nice work environment and facilities (gym, cafeteria has nice options, free snacks, free drinks)
2. Eco-friendly management.
3. Cool technology.
4. People who care about what they do.
cons:
1. Lots of management change.  Lots of directors, VPs, etc. being hired but very little hiring below that level.  

2. Strange spans of control--some manager have lots of direct reports and others have few or none.    Title inflation?  Not clear compensation is based on effort and level of responsibility.

3.  HR is not good.  Instituted non-exempt classification for different groups of employees and gave them a cut in pay at the same time.  Plus, HR wasn't prepared to address employee concerns.  Bad for morale.

review_title: I used to love the company but they have gone through massive upper management changes and its not all for the good.
job_title: Senior Manager in Palo Alto, CA
pros: lots of employees freebies, micro kitchens, supporting charities both monetarily and by encouraging employees to give up to 40 hours a year in work.
cons: lots of upper management change going on and its hard to feel as if it is a stable environment. Although the company is doing well and upward trajectory, bonuses in some departments were allocated less than 100% even for top rated employees.  Contradictory to the success of the company

review_title: Was a good place to work
pros: Good pay Bad Management. It's all about Micromanagement place is a nightmare to work at.  The employees who have been here 5+ years are good the newer ones have just taken the company into the dump.
cons: No Wordlife balance at all. Week nights weekends just about anytime of the day you are required to work. They have taken the fun out of work and turned it into spreadsheets and admin work. There is no more technical enablement to stay current on the technology.  Spread to thin to get your work completed and too many inner politics of sales vs engineers. I loved the company when I joined a few years ago and now I'm just looking for a way out.

job_title: Senior Director in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Beautiful campus. Cafeteria serves great food. Great parking structure where employees do not need to park their cars under the sun. Campus is so beautiful that they are subletting part of the campus to Tesla Motors.
cons: The company is no longer the VMware we came to know and love many years ago. The internally created EPIC value is mostly marketing but no one at the management level believe in it. This is apparent given how certain VPs are misusing internal funds for a variety of reasons.

pros:
Employees make you feel equal to them rather than like an intern, giving you meaningful work. I very much felt like a member of the team. I knew that my work actually had an impact on the constant forward development of Airwatch, which not many interns can say.

The corporate culture is also enjoyable. There are many smart young professionals that, for me, provided a way to ask questions about my future career and what my next step should be. They also have professional panels in which the higher-ups come in and give their career stories and insight on how their beginnings went. It was very helpful.
cons: I have heard from other employees that working full time is a ton of work. Very much is expected of all employees and it can be very stressful, and work life balance can be interrupted often for some.

pros: Relaxed environment. You will get enough time to know the products. Most of  the managers are very cooperative. Salary is very good. Stock option  is very good. Plenty of awesome colleagues. Free snacks and breakfast.
cons: Some nasty people  bully new employees, if they are from a different community.  these guys are very communal. Some of them get promoted only because they know people of their own community  working in vmware USA. They misbehave with newly appointed employees. Some of them  bypass their managers to get a promotion. They sabotage newly appointed colleagues so that they fail to perform. Knowledge hiding is a common thing here.

review_title: Find the right manager and you will be happy
pros:
Great benefits. Great salary.  Great brand name.

If you are applying to their vRA team in the Burlington MA branch, you need to be aware which team you are interviewing for. There are two managers for the VRA team at their Burlington MA office. One of the manager's team has a great culture where the smartest thrive.
The other manager hires people mostly from one specific country.  He avoids Americans probably because his ability to manipulate and oppress them is lesser.  His team is extremely toxic with hand picked idiots on the top.  Idiots who are very loyal to him and will never revolt against him.
cons: Join the right manager's team and be happy. Join the wrong manager's team and expect to descend into a hell of dirty politics and sucking up.

pros: The techology is really cutting edge, and VMware has a very high proportion of people who are both really smart and fun to be around.  Solving really hard problems is ingrained in the company's culture, and we are the uncontested leaders in the red-hot virtualization space.
cons: The company has been growing really fast, and not all areas of the company have scaled gracefully.  Since the company went public, there has been a lot of pressure to contain growth and costs, and as a result some perks (such as free lunches on Wednesdays) have been taken away.

review_title: Great Technology, but overall a mixed bag to work for...
job_title: Senior Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Great access to technology and chance to work with some very smart people.   Good Compensation.  Company is always so good exposure to ecosystem and like-minded products.
cons: Internal processes are not mature at all due to rapid growth.   Not enough collaboration yet between internal (business units, development) and client-facing roles (consultants, sales engineers).  Employee enablement for growth is very sparse. Middle management not effective. Depending on the group you work for, can be very cliquey.

pros: I love the company culture which is more well-rounded than the average Silicon Valley high profile public companies.  If I have to compare it with other companies,  it's somewhere in between Google and Amazon - have some fun, well respected in the enterprise world, but not as crazy as Amazon in the work/life balance.
cons: It's become a lot bigger and less growth opportunities available for new comers or even old-timers. It has the potential to become Oracle/IBM - that's a double-edge sword - and currently it's a bit uncertain if/when VMware does acquire the parent company, EMC.
